headline: Finance Minister Reveals Withheld Text in Reserve Bank Saga as Parliament Clashes Over Housing and Foreign Policy
summary: Parliament was dominated by a major revelation from the Finance Minister regarding the resignation of the Reserve Bank Governor, admitting she was aware of an employment process months earlier than previously disclosed. The admission came during a fiery Question Time that also saw the coalition government grilled over contradictory housing policies and a heated debate on Palestinian statehood that descended into personal accusations. The day concluded with the formal commencement of the Estimates Debate, where the government's new budget faced its first round of intense scrutiny.

topicSummaries.topic: Finance Minister Reveals Withheld Text on Reserve Bank Governor's Exit
topicSummaries.content: Under questioning from Labour's Barbara Edmonds, Finance Minister Nicola Willis revealed she was informed via text message on February 27 that the Reserve Bank board had begun an "employment process" concerning Governor Adrian Orr. Willis stated she was told Orr had been given a "board statement of concern on his conduct." This information had previously been withheld under an Official Information Act request, which Willis defended as appropriate at the time to protect an ongoing employment matter, but judged it was now in the public interest to release following an Ombudsman's ruling.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Barbara Edmonds (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Why was the contents of that text on 27 February withheld under the Official Information Act (OIA)?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Nicola Willis (Minister of Finance)
keyExchanges.quote: They inform me that it was withheld under section 9(ba)(i), which is to protect information which is subject to an obligation of confidence likely to prejudice the supply of information of that sort in future. I have judged that it is in the public interest for me to share the contents of that text message with Parliament today.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Faces Grilling Over Contradictory Housing Price Goals
topicSummaries.content: Leader of the Opposition Chris Hipkins challenged Acting Prime Minister David Seymour on the government's seemingly contradictory public statements on house prices. Hipkins highlighted that the Prime Minister wants "modest, consistent house price increases," while the Housing Minister has said the government is "trying to drive house prices down." Seymour attempted to reconcile the positions, arguing the government's goal is to make building easier through regulatory reform, which would make housing more affordable, while a growing economy would naturally see New Zealanders become wealthier and potentially bid prices up.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Leader of the Opposition)
keyExchanges.quote: So was Christopher Luxon wrong when he said that the Government wants, "modest, consistent house price increases"?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon David Seymour (Acting Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: It reminds me of when I used to tutor Econ 101. Let me explain to the Leader of the Opposition: on the one hand, we want New Zealanders to be wealthier, we want our population to grow, we want people to be bidding to raise house prices, but on the other hand, we want to make it easier to build them.

topicSummaries.topic: Heated Debate on Palestinian Statehood Sees Minister Accused of 'Blood-Quantum' Remarks
topicSummaries.content: Foreign Affairs Minister Winston Peters faced questions from Green Co-leader Marama Davidson on why New Zealand has not yet joined other Western nations in recognizing a Palestinian state. The exchange became intensely personal when Peters, responding to interjections from Te Pāti Māori, made a comment directed at Co-leader Debbie Ngarewa-Packer distinguishing between "half-Māori" and "real ones." Ngarewa-Packer raised a point of order, calling the language inappropriate and an example of "blood-quantum," prompting the Speaker to announce he would review the official Hansard record before ruling.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Winston Peters (Minister of Foreign Affairs)
keyExchanges.quote: No, no, no, no—not half-Māori; I mean real ones. Not the Irish Packers—not Irish Packers.

keyExchanges.speaker: Debbie Ngarewa-Packer (Co-Leader—Te Pāti Māori)
keyExchanges.quote: I take exception to the language that was used by the previous speaker suggesting blood quantum and that Māori should be considered "part". That is unparliamentary language.

topicSummaries.topic: Budget Debate Ignites Over $200M Oil and Gas Co-Investment Fund
topicSummaries.content: The first day of the Estimates Debate saw the government's budget face scrutiny, with a key flashpoint being the $200 million contingency for co-investment in oil and gas exploration. Green Co-leader Chlöe Swarbrick argued this constituted a fossil fuel subsidy that could violate international trade agreements, citing the definition in the Agreement on Climate Change, Trade, and Sustainability (ACCTS). Associate Finance Minister Chris Bishop defended the policy, insisting it was a commercial "investment" to de-risk New Zealand's energy supply and not a subsidy, comparing it to the Crown's existing ownership stake in energy companies.

keyExchanges.speaker: Chlöe Swarbrick (Co-Leader—Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Based on those two premises, on those principles, this meets the definition of a subsidy under the Agreement on Climate Change, Trade, and Sustainability. So I'd just really like to understand how the Minister can consistently say the opposite, when he has not addressed the definition and the ACCTS.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Bishop (Associate Minister of Finance)
keyExchanges.quote: The Government, via an investment vehicle that is owned by the Crown, investing in a new gasfield, alongside private sector co-investment, is just an investment. It would be different if the Government was going along and saying, "We are going to pay you money in order to do something." We're not doing that. It's a co-investment on commercial terms... and, therefore, it is not a subsidy.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Announces Major Overhaul of Auckland Transport Governance
topicSummaries.content: Transport Minister Chris Bishop announced a significant restructuring of Auckland's transport governance, fulfilling a government promise to restore local democracy. Under the plan, most transport functions, including policy, planning, and capital projects, will shift from the semi-independent body Auckland Transport directly to Auckland Council. The government argues this will make elected councillors directly accountable to residents for local transport issues. A new Auckland regional transport committee will also be established to develop a 30-year strategic plan for the city.

keyExchanges.speaker: Dan Bidois (National—Northcote)
keyExchanges.quote: How does this change restore local democracy in Auckland?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Chris Bishop (Minister of Transport)
keyExchanges.quote: We are making Auckland Council directly responsible for local roads again so that when Aucklanders raise concerns with their elected local representatives, they actually have levers to do something about it.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Touts Success of Elective Surgery Boost, Exceeding Target by 50%
topicSummaries.content: Health Minister Simeon Brown announced the government's 'Elective Boost' initiative had delivered 16,005 additional surgeries by June 30, exceeding its target by over 50%. He stated this has helped reduce the total elective treatment waitlist by 9% and the number of people waiting more than four months by 22%. However, Labour's Dr Ayesha Verrall challenged the Minister on the value for money and transparency of outsourcing surgeries to private providers, questioning why Health New Zealand will not release the price it pays per procedure, unlike ACC.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr Ayesha Verrall (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Why, when ACC releases the price per procedure that they pay for surgeries, won't Health New Zealand release that information for private surgeries?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Simeon Brown (Minister of Health)
keyExchanges.quote: I'm advised that Health New Zealand at this time is going through further procurement processes with nationally consistent terms, and it is important that they are able to maintain a competitive market. Ultimately, we've allocated funds, and our focus is on making sure that we deliver outcomes for patients and get those treatments done sooner.

conclusion: The day was defined by a major government concession on transparency regarding the Reserve Bank, even as it faced fierce opposition over contradictory policies and the social costs of its new budget.
